head.title: Depicting Women's Work: A Carnival of Roles

hedline.hl1: Depicting Women's Work: A Carnival of Roles

abstract.p: Exhibition assessing women's role in American culture is set to open, Tribeca, New York City; artists Merry Conway and Noni Pratt are primarily responsible for show; photo (S)

block.p: MANY an artist worked from sun to sun to construct the exhibition ''A Woman's Work Is Never Done.'' The exhibition, an end-of-the-century assessment of women's roles in American culture, will begin on Wednesday and continue through June 21 at Hudson Square, a sprawling commercial expanse on Hudson Street that was once home to a furniture showroom.

The project is described as a ''living museum'' by Merry Conway and Noni Pratt, the artists primarily responsible for this show. It is part vaudeville, part installation and inspired by a fun-house or carnival atmosphere. (Ms. Pratt is shown at left performing in one exhibit.)

The exhibition, an end-of-the-century assessment of women's roles in American culture, will begin on Wednesday and continue through June 21 at Hudson Square, a sprawling commercial expanse on Hudson Street that was once home to a furniture showroom.

The project is described as a ''living museum'' by Merry Conway and Noni Pratt, the artists primarily responsible for this show. It is part vaudeville, part installation and inspired by a fun-house or carnival atmosphere. (Ms. Pratt is shown at left performing in one exhibit.)
Nine actors and two musicians will enliven the displays, and interact with an audience that is encouraged to snoop around the tactile exhibits.

''A Woman's Work Is Never Done,'' Hudson Square, Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 P.M. and 9:15 P.M., Sundays 2 P.M. and 3:15 P.M.; 200 Hudson Street (at Canal Street); free but reservations must be made in advance; (212) 334-9365.
